title: (x) "Cr�t-Dessous" wine label - hand lettered {Magnus}
content:
hello folks   
for my uncles winery (in the french part of Switzerland) i would like to digitize some old wine-labels (see attachment). does anyone have an idea what fonts were used � especially the one for �CR�T-DESSOUS� and �Epesses� as they been used for ages now. probably i'll have to redraw though. The font/s for the other elements are open to discussion, so suggestions are more then welcome.   
Thank you all in advance   
Yves ![wine label](http://web.archive.org/web/20051126212903im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/48288.jpg)
author: john_winter

comments.content:
The "CR�T-DESSOUS" is handlettered.   
"Epesses" looks handlettered as well.   
   
Am I reading this right? Does it say   
Familles Gay & Pestalozzi?
Nothing ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20051126212903im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif) I actually know of a place called Pestalozzi as well. Nothing wrong with that.

Well, back to the original question.   
I think the smaller text will be easier to ID from a larger scan if it is possible to get one.   
   
From where I am viewing this it could look like the "Familles Gay & Pestalozzi" is handlettered as well though I cannot be entirely sure.   
   
As for the "CR�T-DESSOUS" and the "Epesses" I am pretty sure you will have to redraw it yourself.   
   
mksg

so i reckoned � as it (the CR�T-DESSOUS that is) is a funny kind of bastard, innit? as i mentioned, i'm free to change the font for the other elements, which i might do. any way thanks for the help!   
yves   
  ![wine label detail](http://web.archive.org/web/20051126212903im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/48328.jpg)

hehehe   
   
Yes all of that is clearly handlettered.   
   
I suggest you might leaf through a few of   
these pages. Maybe there is something suitable.   
 [script](http://web.archive.org/web/20051126212903/http:/www.myfonts.com/search?PREFS_SET%5BRenderSize%5D=36&PREFS_SET%5BRenderString%5D=Appellation+d%27origine+c%F4ntroll%E9e&search%5Btext%5D=script)   
or take a look at Mike's [Script Font Identification Guide](http://web.archive.org/web/20051126212903/http:/bowfinprintworks.com/ScriptIDGuide.html)   
it is packed with examples.

great, now i know what to do during my lunch-break�   
and thanks again.
